title: The Grain Offering
shortSummary: Leviticus chapter 2 outlines the instructions for the meat (grain) offering, emphasizing the use of fine flour, oil, and frankincense as a pleasing aroma to the Lord. It highlights the role of the priests in offering a memorial portion on the altar and the importance of salt as a covenant symbol. This chapter teaches the significance of holiness, purity, and dedication in offerings to God.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Period after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Aaron's Sons
keyCharacters.description: The priests who receive the grain offerings and perform the ritual burning of the memorial portion on the altar.

keyCharacters.name: Offerer
keyCharacters.description: The individual bringing the meat offering to the Lord, responsible for preparing the offering according to the prescribed instructions.

definitions.definition: A grain offering made of fine flour mixed with oil and frankincense, presented to God as a symbol of dedication and thanksgiving.
A fragrant resin burned as incense, symbolizing prayer and the sweet aroma of worship pleasing to God.
Salt used in offerings symbolizing the enduring and preserving nature of God's covenant with His people.
The part of the offering that the priest burns on the altar as a remembrance and dedication to the Lord.

outline.heading: Instructions for the Grain Offering
outline.description: The chapter begins with detailed instructions for preparing a grain offering using fine flour, oil, and frankincense, emphasizing the burning of a memorial portion by the priests as a sweet aroma to the Lord.

outline.heading: Different Methods of Preparing the Offering
outline.description: Various acceptable forms of the grain offering are described, including cakes baked in an oven, baked in a pan, or fried in a frying pan, all involving fine flour and oil.

outline.heading: Presentation and Priestly Duties
outline.description: The offerer brings the prepared grain offering to the priest, who then presents a memorial portion on the altar while the remainder is given to Aaron and his sons as a holy portion.

outline.heading: Prohibitions and Regulations
outline.description: Leaven and honey are prohibited in the grain offerings, and every offering must be seasoned with salt, symbolizing the covenant and purity required in worship.

outline.heading: Offering of Firstfruits
outline.description: Special instructions are given for the offering of firstfruits, involving green ears of corn dried by fire, oil, and frankincense, with the priest burning a memorial portion as an offering made by fire to the Lord.

application: Offer your gifts and service to God with purity and reverence, ensuring they are prepared according to His standards.
Remember the importance of dedicating the first and best of what God has given you as an act of worship and obedience.
Maintain the 'salt of the covenant' in your life by preserving your commitment to God's promises and living in holiness.
Trust that even small offerings, when given with the right heart, are pleasing to God and have eternal significance.

keyVerses.text: And when any will offer a meat offering unto the LORD, his offering shall be of fine flour; and he shall pour oil upon it, and put frankincense thereon:
keyVerses.significance: This verse establishes the essential elements of the grain offering, symbolizing purity, anointing, and prayerful worship.

keyVerses.text: And every oblation of thy meat offering shalt thou season with salt; neither shalt thou suffer the salt of the covenant of thy God to be lacking from thy meat offering: with all thine offerings thou shalt offer salt.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the necessity of salt as a covenant symbol, reminding believers of the enduring nature of their relationship with God.

keyVerses.text: And the priest shall take from the meat offering a memorial thereof, and shall burn it upon the altar: it is an offering made by fire, of a sweet savour unto the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes the priestly role in offering a memorial portion to God, symbolizing remembrance and dedication.
